texts.shortText:
Small, mainly white gull with grey back and upper wings, outermost primaries black, the outer two with white tips and white flashes. Head with pale lavender-grey ‘hood’ often only visible as a slightly darker line along its lower edge. Eyes dark brown. Bill and legs dark red.

Juveniles with upper parts mottled brown.
Total length 36-38 cm, wingspan 92 cm, mass of male about 290 g, of female 265 g.

Global: Endemic to southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Primarily along west coast from northern Namibia to Cape Agulhas, but recorded in lower numbers as far east as Algoa Bay and vagrants to northern KwaZulu-Natal.

Predominantly a coastal and estuarine species, seldom found far out to sea. Habituate readily to transformed landscapes and common in urban areas, nesting on buildings, bathing in urban ponds and swimming pools and scavenging from bins, picnickers and restaurant tables, etc. About half the total population occur in the greater Cape Town area, where very common.

Omnivorous and under natural conditions feed by snatching prey from the water surface at sea, or small estuarine fish, by puddling for invertebrates in shallow water, on dead animals washed up along the drift-line, on kelp-fly larvae washed out of wrack beds at high tide and the like. Also commonly feed inland, following ploughs, feeding on termite alates, moths, grasshoppers, etc. Commonly scavenge behind trawlers, or from domestic waste, around open-air restaurants and picnic sites, etc.

Historically probably bred only on offshore islands, but now regularly use roofs of buildings. Nest an untidy structure of plant stems. Breeds mostly in winter, laying 1-3 light brown to dark green eggs overlain with brown or grey blotches or scrolls. Incubation period about 25 days, young fed by regurgitation.

Can easily be confused with Grey-headed gull, which is relatively rare on west coast and more common inland and along south and east coasts. That species is also slightly larger with longer legs and bill and has a more pronounced grey hood and pale eyes.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 350).

Hockey, PAR, Dean, WRJ & Ryan, PG (2005). Robert’s Birds of Southern Africa (7th edition). The Trustees of the John Voelckler Book Fund, Cape Town. (p. 444).
